text: great thanks for the introduction again michael and thanks everyone for for coming uh the the topic i wanted to talk about
today is design tools for digital fabrication and um
as many of you may know digital fabrication has become probably one of the most kind of active or hot
topics in computer graphics which is kind of mainly the community that i come from but as well as as well as hci
so you know why have i and to be fair others as well kind of jumped on this this fabrication bandwagon so to speak
well one thing one reason that you've probably heard before is the rise of digital fabrication and
technology so things like 3d printers laser cutters cnc machines these things
are becoming more affordable and more accessible than ever before and that's making it possible to create
a variety of different things in a variety of different materials easier than ever before as well so
i think that that seems to present or offer an opportunity to think about and develop some new
user interfaces and interaction techniques as well as computational tools to help people create this variety
of different types of physical artifacts okay so so that's kind of the status and
i was just i just tried to look back over some of my favorite fabrication papers over the last several years and i
found that you know more or less they kind of fell into three broad categories
so there's been a lot of projects that focus on building design tools that empower new users so these are people
who may not have the expertise to use traditional cad or cam tools to create things
to design for fabrication and so there have been systems we've seen systems for helping people build
kind of complex furniture as well as figurines that can balance and stand on their own
another category of work is just exploring the new types of things that we can create with rapid prototyping
technologies and some of you may have seen the work by willis at all on printed optics where
they embed these 3d printed light pipes inside of objects to create or enable these kind of dynamic and
tangible display surfaces also valkyrie savage and their colleagues at berkeley have been working
on a few different techniques for creating 3d printed tangible input components
like game controllers or mixing boards let's say that are kind of functional they're interactive they work with computers but they don't require you to
actually wire up a bunch of electronics in there they use things like computer vision and audio signal processing to detect
detect and interpret these interaction events and finally there's this kind of interesting category of new work
that's been coming out that really looks to understand the the understand design workflows that make use of digital
fabrication and try to improve or optimize those workflows so in particular um stephanie mueller and her
colleagues at hpi have done a lot of really cool recent work that tries to just you know figure out some of the inefficiencies in existing design
workflows that involve 3d printing and just minimize those those or kind of work on those inefficiencies to try to
make um to try to make design iteration much quicker so these are three kind of broad
categories of work there are probably other ones most of what i'll talk about today falls into this first category um
but i'm interested in these other categories as well and i'm hoping that at some point i get a chance to work on some projects uh in that
in those domains okay so if we're talking about trying to empower new users to design for fabrication who might these users be um
well i think on one hand some of them could very well be industrial designers
so these are people who are already kind of embedded already participating in the
process of creating physical things but in some cases at least not all these designers may have the
kind of engineering or cad expertise to create working physical models on their own so
maybe they have to work with uh mechanical engineers or a print shop and so the opportunity here is i think to
kind of reduce the that kind of friction in the design workflow and hopefully make it easier for designers to create
and fabricate some of these objects themselves and then hopefully thereby iterate more quickly
there's also a large community of makers out there who are interested in creating a wide variety of different types of
objects and again you know these people may not have the expertise to create physical objects completely on their own
and then finally there's you know i think what i would call just a long tail of of
other people um maybe let's just call them consumers this is kind of a like a really common term that's bandied
about in in adobe probably other companies as well it's like oh this is a block of people they're consumers it means they're
willing to spend money on something but for consumers i think for these
consumers the interest may be more in terms of just kind of personalizing some of the objects that they that they buy
or they have in uh in their possession so maybe putting uh photographs on their on their iphone cases or
maybe designing exactly you know which combinations of colors or materials your shoe should be composed of so
you know this is kind of a they're a very different i think segment than uh designers and makers but they're still
kind of interested in participating in the this kind of design process at some level
so in addition to having all these different types of of a potential users you know obviously there's lots of
different domains of physical objects that we might consider when we're thinking about building design tools so
you know clothing and furniture and jewelry maybe even you want to design your own modern prefab house
so each of these domains probably uh consists of some of
or produces some of its own challenges with respect to developing effective design
tools um in the last part of my talk i will discuss what i think are some opportunities that kind of may span some
of the many of these different categories but for most of today i'll be talking about some work that falls under the category
of kind of mechanism design and in particular i'll talk about two
projects one that focuses more on kind of enabling hobbyists to create
great working mechanical objects and the other one that focuses more on on designers
okay so why are mechanical objects kind of an interesting domain to look at
well first of all they're extremely common and you know you may be thinking about things like cars and construction
equipment and other kind of industrial machinery these are clearly all examples of mechanical objects but kind of at a
smaller more kind of day-to-day scale things like there are things like toys like wind up toys for instance and also
just lots of household objects consist of mechanical components so um there are lots of these mechanical
objects out there and the other thing is that they they tend to be pretty difficult to to design so
there's lots of parameters that are associated with these mechanical objects and those parameters are coupled and constrained in interesting and
challenging ways so there may be kind of like a pretty big parameter space of designs to consider but only a
relatively small set is is actually valid or it does what you wanted to do and so while you know people with a
mechanical engineering background or an industrial design background may be capable of kind of finding the this
right set of parameters it can be a pretty daunting task for um you know for other designers or for hobbyists and
certainly for novices so you know the the question is how can we kind of help these different types of
users create some of these mechanical mechanical objects okay so so before i get into the
specifics of a couple these two projects that i'll talk about in this space i wanted to take a brief diversion and
since michael mentioned at the beginning i want to talk a little bit about some other work that i've done previously
just to give some context for how i got interested in mechanism design in the first place so
a problem that i've been interested in for a long time is how can we help people
visualize and understand the the structure the internal structure of complex 3d objects that contain lots of
different parts so you that um so you know for instance anatomical models or or cad model these
are examples of the types of data sets that i'm interested in and during my phd i worked on a bunch of interactive
visualization techniques that are inspired by traditional technical illustrations so cutaways and exploded
views and tries to kind of automate these techniques as much as possible so that um we can have a kind of
interactive viewing experience and so what you're seeing here are is just some videos of these two systems where for
instance the user can just search for the parts that they care about and the system will automatically generate either a cutaway or exploded view that
just shows you those parts the these systems also support other types of interaction like hovering over parts
and also clicking on parts uh to kind of explore these types of objects a little bit more interactively
okay so so these types of systems um one thing that they help people do is understand the kind of spatial
configurations of parts that exist inside of these objects but but one really common
comment that we got from people who saw this this work was okay that's great but i really i really also want to know how these things work
like how does this engine work it's got lots of moving parts in it i guess people
did not ask how much how the arm works so for anatomical data sets it was a little bit different but especially for these cad data sets they were like you
know i really want to know not just where all these parts are inside of these objects but but how they
work and so that kind of led us to some follow-on work where we looked exactly at that at that
question and so in this work we took as input a 3d model so this is
just geometry know what kind of other annotations and then given uh given a specification
of some kind of driving input uh driving force uh at some part um what we tried to do is to create
visualizations that show how these things are trying to convey how these things actually functioned
and some of our a lot of our visualization techniques were inspired by
the how things work books that michael mentioned earlier so for instance these types of kind of uh
motion arrows that annotate where the mechanical interactions occur and also you know how how the parts move
but we were also inspired by a lot of cognitive psychology research that really emphasized the importance of the
so-called kind of causal chain of mechanical interactions uh in understanding you know how these things actually work and so here here's a
different visualization that just highlights each step in the this causal chain um how the the the force kind of
gets propagated throughout these this assembly in particular and then of course um since we have this
information about about how the since we know something about how this assembly actually works we can also create um animations uh like the one you
shoot like the one you see here they're kind of in an illustrative style but show the the assembly in motion
so i don't want to go into too much detail exactly on on um how this this technique actually
works but i did want to describe the high level approach because i think it's relevant to some of the subsequent parts
of the talk so the high level approach was we took an input model on the left again this is just geometry
and then we did some geometric analysis in order to figure out
you know how this thing actually works and in particular we construct a graph we call it an interaction graph but
there are other names for it in um in the literature as well where each of the nodes represents an individual part and
the edges represent these mechanical interactions between parts so this graph really kind of
defines or encodes the the functionality the mechanical functionality of of the um of
the object and based on this graph we can derive all the different visualizations that i
just showed you so that was kind of the overall approach okay so what does this have to do with
um mechanism design so after working on this project project it
kind of occurred to us that one thing we could try to do is kind of turn this approach on its head and maybe use that as a as an approach to helping people
design physical objects or working mechanical objects so in particular let's say
as opposed to taking an input model and then trying to figure out how it functions maybe we can ask
people to specify some desired kind of goal functionality and then use that
as part of our system as part of a design system to help people create working
working mechanical physical designs so that's kind of the the really high level approach that the next couple
projects i'll talk about take and you know just to be really clear here um
you know this this is certainly not a really a new idea i mean i'm not a i'm not an expert in mechan mechanical
engineering but i know there's a ton of work on inverse design this is basically an inverse design approach on inverse
design that focuses on you know helping engineers create things like uh optimize the
design of turbines and airfoils and gear trains that accomplish specific design goals um maybe bill can say more about
this at some point but you know there's a lot of work out there that does that my impression is that a lot of
this this existing work um does still kind of focus on you know how can we help a mechanical engineer solve
a particularly a particular a specific challenging design problem and as a result a lot of the kind of input
functionality in its previous work i think tends to be somewhat low level so here's a desired kind of gear ratio for
two particular gears in a gear train now you know how can we help help the engineer create that the corresponding
mechanism so what we we've been interested in exploring are some methods and some user interfaces as well
that kind of allow for users to specify some higher level functionality and hopefully
in doing so kind of open up some applications that are that are relevant to people like you know like like the hobbyists
and the designers and maybe even the novices that i talked about uh earlier okay so that's uh that's kind of the
basic approach and um let's see did we just jump right in yeah so let's just jump right in and i'll
talk about two these two projects uh that i've worked on recently so the first one is really focusing on
hobbyists as a kind of a as a target audience and the goal is to help them create um mechanical automata and so
these are things like what you see here so on the left these are actually example uh mechanical
toys from the 19th century um and so they these automata tend to look more or
less like humans and repor perform some kind of repetitive motions and they're all mechanically driven so typically
this is one kind of input crank and you turn it and the thing kind of does you know performs these these repeated
motions um but you know mechanical automata are not just things of the past
they exist in our in our current lives as well and um you know one one common example are just wind-up toys
there's lots of kind of toys out there that are still largely mechanical um but you know even
like in things like uh stage production and i think theme parks they still use things that we could more
or less call mechanical automata to create these kind of like um moving characters moving physical characters and uh although i i'm not an
expert in the visual effects i believe that up until recently visual effects still also used in some cases you know
mechanical automata to to create certain types of certain types of creatures and those
kinds of things so you know these are some really interesting types of mechanisms but
obviously or maybe not obviously it they're hard to design i mean you have to worry about a whole bunch of
interacting mechanical components and have them kind of achieve these specific target um target motions so the goal in
this project was just just to try to make it easier for easier for for users who are not
mechanical engineers who are not expert toy designers to create these kinds of of outputs
in particular the the approach the kind of design pipeline that we took was to have people specify as input some kind
of motion and this is in the form of an animation in this case it's motion capture animation so let's say we have
this input motion then what the system helps user do in a largely automated way is to turn that
into a mechanically realizable form of that motion that in you know that also has has
solved for all the different mechanical parameters of the parts that that will create that motion and again in this case we are trying to work with this
kind of single input crank constraint so this thing can should be able to be driven by a single input crank
okay and then based on that design we can now actually fabricate a working version of the of the automata
automaton by in this case laser cutting the different parts and then putting them
putting them together okay so just a little bit more detail on how this
actually works i won't go into a lot of detail kind of one of the main
insights one of the main um kind of uh aspects of the technique was you know as i mentioned before um
we're trying to allow users to provide some really high level functionality here and that makes things challenging like
there's lots of different ways of achieving any any of these input motions right and so that's a pretty huge parameter space of different
configurations that we could consider um how do we kind of make that problem a little bit more tractable so the way
that we did it in this case um the the the way we had of simplifying the problem was to
come up with a single fixed uh what we call oscillation module that has this you know fixed design has
certain sets of gears and in this case a four bar linkage that's connected to the gears to kind of turn
rotational motion into oscillating motion and then we attach these oscillation modules to each joint in in the
in the model so now we have basically the same repeated design it's just a modular it's a modular design that's
repeated across all the different joints which really reduces the kind of the space of different solutions we have to search over um so it's not quite as
simple as this actually we you know we have this um this you know kind of a four-bar linkage we also connect that
that linkage to the next limb inside of each of the the kind of kinematic chains of the body so that you see those black
limbs kind of moving back and forth and then finally in order to be able to propagate the motion from you know one
joint to the next so let's say the shoulder to the elbow then we we attach this kind of pulley mechanism that then
kind of allows the initial kind of driving rotation to be transferred to the next the next joint in the chain so
this is kind of the basic um design element of this technique and
with this oscillation module we basically run an optimization that takes that input motion and then comes up with an
approximated motion as well as the design that kind of um solves for all the parameters of the of the module
now i i should say here there's definitely a trade-off here i mean we on the one hand we've we've created this
oscillation module that makes the the parameters you know that reduces the parameter space we have to care about
but on the flip side it also kind of restricts the range of different motions that we can produce right and so um that is kind of the fundamental
tradeoff that we decided to make um in spite of that we were able to use this approach to to kind of reproduce an
interesting range of different motions so let me just show you a few results here um so on the left is in each case is the input motion the middle is kind
of the mechanical motion so it's we're not showing the mechanisms just yet but we're just showing you know the
difference between the input motion and the motion that we're more or less able to achieve mechanically with these oscillation modules um
so one one constraint here is that we're restricting the motion of any individual um
chain like the arms or the legs to be planar but those can exist in different so the arms can move in a different plane than
the legs it's just that you know each arm or each leg has to have a more or less a planar motion
so these are a bunch of different motions that we grab from a motion capture data set
and in a minute here you'll see a couple of the fabricated results oh yeah we can also use like you know a
connect or something to then demonstrate the desired input motion and then produce a
design that reproduces that motion more or less so on the fabrication side um you know
this is the walking example that you saw earlier uh we laser cut all these different parts including the the the
limbs and then we um we were able to fabricate this example and we're driving here with
it with a motor at the top it's kind of hidden i think but it's it's being driven from the top
and then there's in a moment here the second sequence the dancing sequence which has two different planes of motion the arms kind of move this way and the
legs move in another plane and so that's that's this example here
okay so i already talked about some of the limitations of this work um they mainly have to do with our use of this
kind of this fixed oscillation module um as i said you know we the right now the
motion of each individual limb has to be in a single plane which is fine for some motions but let's say for swimming in
the swimming example it really probably wouldn't work very well also as i mentioned we are assuming
there's a single input crank that can drive any of these individual um individual designs which is on the one
hand good because you know if you have a wind-up toy you have basically a single input and you know that's great
but on the other hand it can make for some pretty complicated like we have to jump through some hoops actually get all
these different chains connected up all these different kind of moving parts connected up so that they can be driven by a single a single input crank so that
definitely some more work i think that needs to be done there in order to make these kind of simpler designs and then
finally the individual mechanical components we use inside of our oscillation module they're really simple they're just gears
and four bar linkages and pulleys which again restricts the range of different types of motions that we can
we can produce potentially so if we consider things like non-circular gears or more complicated linkages i think
that could really expand the range of things we could reproduce and in fact some other kind of recent work along these lines
does experiment with some of these different types of components
okay so so the system for for um authoring automata that was
really focused on on hobbyists and so as a result we were trying to go for like a fairly automated system we more or less
provide this input motion and then the system generates a result for you um so that's fine for hobbyists but what if we
want to consider other types of users for instance industrial designers who you know
like they're probably going to want to be creating a wide variety of different types of things and as a result
a design system for for those types of users probably needs to be kind of more flexible and give them more
control over the types of things that they can create so that was kind of the direction we moved in for this for
this other project where we're really focusing on on designers and helping them create
prototypes in particular we are focusing on
what some people call works like prototypes and so these are prototypes that are you know often
created i think earlier on in the design process to try to explore the um kind of the the functional
characteristics of a particular candidate design this is especially true for for mechanical objects um
in many cases the actual you know geometry or the appearance of these prototypes doesn't have to be very
accurate um the point is not to try to evaluate how the thing looks or the form of the um of the candidate design is
more about the mechanical functionality in some designers called the mechanical
architecture of these of these objects um you know this probably
is pretty kind of well well agreed upon well understood at this point
all the various benefits of prototyping and so in particular creating these works like prototypes i think can really
help um uh help designers go through multiple iterations in the design cycle which can
lead to often leads to kind of better design exploration so
the goal here is to try to make it easier for these designers to create these kinds of works like prototypes and then contribute to this some
better design exploration as a result
so the the main challenge that we kind of um uh identified here in talking and
talking to some designers about their process is that going from the concept of some kind of
mechanical design to uh to a working prototype of that design is often kind of challenging i mean even
if it's a relatively simple even if the the prototype is relatively simple geometry as you see here um there's lots
of things to think about like you know where to put the joints what are the joint parameters what are the dimensions
of all the parts so that everything kind of fits together nicely so you know
going from design to to to these working prototypes involves kind of addressing some of these challenges and while some
designers are are probably capable of doing that um many others kind of have to rely on working with engineers or um or
other kind of experts cad experts to try to help them do this and so this is kind of the the part of the of the workflow
that we were trying to trying to address and trying to um facilitate
okay so the specific design pipeline that we uh that we adopt is from a design we
we um we have the we expect that the the user is going to create a really rough model
of the object so in this case you don't have to worry so much about exactly how the parts line up you know where the
joint should go exactly um uh the various joint parameters just kind of create a rough model that's
that's based on your initial design and then what we allow
the user to do is now specify specific functional relationships between different parts of this of this design
or different parts of this of this 3d model in this case so for instance you might say that one part of the model has
to cover another part of the model or you might say that one part of the
the design has to fit inside another part of the design another another functional relationship
we support is support so one object should be supported by other one part should be supported by other parts inside of the
design so by specifying these kind of functional relationships the user is
kind of telling us something about what is the desired functionality of this object that they've kind of roughly modeled
so based on this this information we're able to kind of create or update the the initial rough
model and turn that into a working design so now the part dimensions have been updated to
to match or to satisfy all these functional requirements and also we've generated joints and joint parameters
joints with the appropriate joint parameters to allow this design to actually work and then we can send this design to uh let's say a
3d printer or some other rapper prototyping technology and then get a working prototype in the end
okay so i'll just say a little bit more again i'm not going to say a lot about exactly how this works but
you know basically one of the the key contributions here was just figuring out a way of mapping these functional
relationships which you know are specified at a really high level like you know this this part of the cabinet
has to cover this other part of the cabinet mapping those onto a set of geometric constraints that we could then
use inside of an optimization to take that rough initial model and turn it into a working model
so let me just show you a little bit of the system in action so here's this kind of rough initial model let's
say i want these two doors of this of this this cabinet to actually fit or cover exactly the front of the
cabinet so if i specify that relationship you can see you know a bunch of the part dimensions have been updated to make sure that that's the
case and also to avoid collisions this is kind of an example of a fit inside relationship this is pretty
pretty clear so i want this drawer to fit just inside of the the printer cabinet um so that gets
updated and in this case i'm saying i want the top of this kind of folding uh bunk bed thing to kind of be supported
by by all the parts underneath of it and this is kind of the update that the system makes
so one advantage of having these functional relationships kind of explicitly encoded in the system is that
once we have them we can also allow the user to explore design variations while maintaining these functional
relationships so here you know i say oh the doors have to cover the front of the cabinets and they also in this case have
to fit inside so you know those those relationships relationships are known so now as i
change the size of these different components the entire cabinet updates appropriately
okay so now given given these designs i'll just show here a few of the fabricated prototypes

and you know i guess as this plays i'll just talk again a bit about a couple of the limitations of this approach so you
know these examples just demonstrate to some extent the range of different objects that we were able to to produce
but you know we're right now only supporting really simple geometric primitives you know i said at the outset that works like prototypes tend to have
pretty simple geometry that's true but sometimes you know just having boxes and cylinders is not

case for an iphone let's say or something along those lines so even if the actual geometry of the
of the of the parts of the prototype don't need to be particularly detailed having those parts fit with
other real objects is kind of a nice a nice feature and so you know i think clearly to make this
this approach more more useful we'd want to consider these different types of different types of geometric primitives

other functional relationships i think could be important again that same designer mentioned uh
snap fitting as a as one potential um relationship or like yeah kind of like

okay so these are you know just kind of two points in the space
but there has actually been a lot of work recently in the in the graphics and hci
communities on things related to to mechanism design and so um you know some of this work is very
related to things that i showed um others are kind of less related like for instance on the bottom right it's a cool
paper from siggraph last year where they're creating things that spin so basically you take a 3d model as input
and you want to try to make it spin like a top so you know that's kind of a functional goal that somebody might have and so that's um that's what that work
focuses on um so these are just two points in the space i you know and there's lots of
kind of work going on in in this area right now i do think though that there's lots more work that could be done so i
think this is a pretty open space lots of different domains and different types of functionality that you can imagine trying to like
support in these kinds of design systems and i just wanted to show one specific example of a it's kind of an
inspirational example of something that that i saw again at this graph last year that made me think about an interesting
new direction that i think is worth worth pursuing so some of you may have heard of
not impossible labs uh but they gave the keynote at um siggraph last year
and what they do is they try to go out and use technology to to try to solve specific problems for specific people so
in this case um this boy daniel who uh uh lives in a village in sudan was you
know tragically lost both of his arms in a in an embalming and they went and they
built him a prosthetic arm that allowed him to um eat by himself so basically in moving the arm um er moving the arm
kind of also control the the hand of the of the arm so he could kind of reach out grab things and then bring them up to

only did they build a single solution they tried to basically educate um the rest of the village and this in some
sense kind of open source the solution so that other people could actually build similar kinds of
prosthetics based on the same design and i thought that was you know really like it's a really simple observation
it's a really actually noble kind of um uh goal but the simple observation was that
you know it took us a lot of it took a lot of expertise and effort to actually create this one working design
now how can we leverage that as much as possible to help other people kind of take advantage of that and so
i think um there's to me there seems like at least a couple of different well this is one kind of main opportunity here from kind
of a computer graphics or hdi research side which is that i think if we can think about ways of taking
individual working designs and then parameterizing them in ways that makes it make it easier for those designs to
be kind of adapted to different situations so clearly in the case of the prosthetic like everyone's got a different arm
different shaped arm you know there's clearly parameters that have to be kind of customized that's an interesting problem i think
and i think it's one that's worth worth trying to address so
that's kind of the the that's kind of where i'll leave off the first part of my talk which is really focusing on

let me go back to this slide from the beginning of my talk as i started out with started out by

thinking about that i think is um you know could be interesting to work on um so let me start with a bit of an
observation we've talked a lot about functionality and in particular mechanical functionality but those
clearly are not the only design goals that go into making physical objects the one ones that we see in the world around
us and just as a couple of examples you know this this sculpture by rodin is not just a
kind of anatomically plausible representation of a reclining figure that happens to balance and you know sit
flat on a surface just like you know this these chairs are not just some
collection of wood and metal and fiberglass that you know that a human can sit on i mean
clearly they have a functional purpose but that's not the only that's not the only goal here
you know for these objects as well as many others the the artists and designers who are creating them are using a variety of
techniques to kind of um convey certain emotions or convey certain aspects that are beyond just
function and i think it's interesting for us to maybe think about how we could
try to be inspired by and leverage some of these uh some of these existing techniques
that that artists and designers have created in order to build better computational tools
um so as a uh as a computer graphics person it occurred to me that um there's a
potential an analogy we could draw here to the advent of um a field called non-photorealistic rendering which some
of you may have heard about um basically you know in the history of computer graphics um
people started out for a long time just trying to create more and more realistic renderings images of of you know 3d
models of things that exist in the world today trying to emulate um emulate reality as much as possible and
